author: mrabino1
content: has any research been done on the approximate time needed for the post1559 fee market to stabilize?  (asking from the perspective of the miner and future validator)

author: mrabino1
content: i suspect it will be well within the first hour .. (but this also assumes all miners expand the gas limit to 30MM)

author: trent_vanepps
content:
it really depends what you mean by stabilize, and depends on several variables, including 

- tx demand heading into the fork
- whether all miners update and maintain the same block gas limit (like you mentioned)

author: trent_vanepps
content:
> the baseFeePerGas will be set to 1 gwei. This means that, at first, transactions will be competing via a first-price auction on the tip, as the baseFeePerGas reaches the rate where there is ~15m gas /100% demand at that price.
> 
> If you assume the market price is 250 gwei on the fork date, this means that baseFeePerGas needs to go through ~50 blocks to get there, or slightly less than 15 minutes.

obviously we are no longer in a 250 gwei regime, so this should be lower. read more here on the Cheatsheet I put together with Tim: https://hackmd.io/4YVYKxxvRZGDto7aq7rVkg?view

author: terra854
content: Just wondering, is it possible for the mining pool operators to decide on how many txs to include in a block? Cause if that is so, they can be able to manipulate BASEFEE in a way by purposely not filling up the block to the max when they mine the block

author: peter.davies
content: This has been extensively analysed and the conclusion is that they can't achieve anything by doing this and it will just cost them money.

author: peter.davies
content: If they have more than 51% of miners colluding they can start causing problems, but the entire security of Ethereum depends on 51% of miners not colluding anyway.
